item.title: Along the River during the Qingming Festival
item.description: Along the River During the Qingming Festival is a panoramic painting generally attributed to the Song Dynasty artist Zhang Zeduan. It captures the daily life of people from the Song period in the capital, Bianjing, today’s Kaifeng in Henan.

item.title: Chinese Bronze Mirrors
item.description: It seems so natural for us to carefully dress up in front of a mirror every day. However, before the invention of glass, mirrors were made of copper. To be more exact, they were bronze mirrors.

item.title: Chinese Embroidery
item.description: The earliest examples of Chinese embroidery stem from the Zhou Dynasty. These might well represent the origin of embroidery, but early examples of which have also been discovered in ancient Egypt and northern Europe, though there was no conclusive proof of exactly where embroidery originated.

item.title: Chinese Jade Burial Suits
item.description: Just fifteen of the extraordinary head-to-toe jade suits that promised immortality to the Chinese imperial family have ever been found. The ancient Chinese believe that when a person dies, he or she will enter into the afterlife.

item.title: Chinese Paper-Cut
item.description: Paper-cut is a very distinctive visual art of Chinese handicrafts. It originated from the 6th century when women used to paste golden and silver foiled cuttings onto their hair at the temples, and men used them in sacred rituals.

item.title: Chinese Porcelain
item.description: Chinese ceramics show a continuous development since pre-dynastic times and are one of the most significant forms of Chinese art and ceramics globally. Porcelain is so identified with China that it is still called “china” in everyday English usage.

item.title: Chinese Seals
item.description: Chinese seal engraving can be traced back to more than 3,000 years ago to the Shang Dynasty when the inscriptions on tortoise shells and bronze were available for recording happenings and ideas of human beings.

item.title: Chinese Shadow Puppetry
item.description: Shadow puppetry, also known as shadow play, is one of China’s historic folk arts. Performed by three to five puppeteers, shadow puppetry is a form of storytelling that uses puppets against an illuminated backdrop to create the illusion of movement.

item.title: Heshi Jade
item.description: From Neolithic times, the Chinese have been extremely fond of jade and have made this magical stone an inseparable part of Chinese culture and art. In China the national passion for jade gave that stone much the same superiority that lapis lazuli had in Sumer and the Chinese saying “Gold has a value; jade is invaluable.
